column3: v. Lead+rhythm. <Gaming terminology> To instigate a fight. This Internet slang term is originally used to describe a gamer who determines the strategies for the whole team in a group video or computer game. column3: v. To root for [someone or something]. This Internet slang term originated from Wotagei or otagei, which refers to a type of dancing and cheering gestures performed by wota, fans of Japanese idol singers (and thus seen as Akiba-kei), involving jumping, clapping, arm-waving and chanting slogans.

column3: n. To lacerate the devils [a term of abuse for foreign invaders, particularly Japanese invaders] by hand. This Internet slang term pokes fun at the 2011 Chinese TV drama The Curious Maestros against Japanese Invasion in which a Kungfu master tears up the Japanese invaders in the War of Resistance against Japan (1937-1945). The plot was berated online and by state-run newspapers like Peopleâ€™s Daily for distorting history.

column3: n. Epic dramas of the War of Resistance against Japan. column3: <Expression> Doesnâ€™t your conscience feel pain? This expression originated from an Internet joke about the bromance between Tang poets Du Fu and Li Bai. The joke claims that Du Fu wrote 12 poems for or about Li Bai, but Li Bai reciprocated with only one poem. The joke writer felt sorry for the â€œmistreatedâ€ Du Fu and questioned Li Bai if he felt guilty for his â€œcrueltyâ€ with the aforementioned expression. Regardless of its original interrogative tone, this expression is now often used humorously to tease someone.

column3: <Expression> What grudge do you hold against me? This expression first became popular in 2014 as a passengerâ€™s reply to another passenger who tried to stop him from cracking melon seeds on the bus. They kept arguing for seven minutes while the melon seed cracker grumbled â€œWhat grudge do you hold against me [so that you keep pestering me]?â€ several times during the process. Rejection of WeChat messages is usually caused by dissatisfaction of the other partyâ€™s opinions or communication styles. column3: n. The old driver. The Internet slang term started off referring to a person who likes talking dirty. The internet meme comes from â€œè€å¸æ©Ÿï¼Œå—šå—šå—š/æ±¡æ±¡æ±¡â€: Old driver, toot, toot, toot/dirty dirty dirty.â€ â€œTootâ€ and â€œdirtyâ€ are homophones. Later, another meaning of this term emerged: a person who is experienced in something. For example, a senior-year student may refer to himself or herself as an old driver because he or she has spent more time at a university than younger students. A veteran salesperson can also describe himself or herself as an old driver in the field.
